text.p: Building products and energy group Boral Ltd said on Thursday that an expected upturn in the housing sector early in 1997 should produce a significant improvement in second half earnings.
It also said performance enhancement programmes would deliver annualised savings of over A$50 million in 1996/97.
Boral said that even though housing starts appeared to have bottomed, the lag in construction meant the current half would remain challenging.
But it said profits in July and August were well ahead of the monthly rate earned in the first half of 1995/96.

"The timing of the upturn in housing is not clear, but most forecasters expect an upturn in the new year which should result in a significant improvement in second half earnings over the comparable period," Boral Managing Director Tony Berg said in a statement with the 1995/96 results.
Earlier, Boral reported a 30 percent fall in net profit to A$205.69 million in the year to June 30, 1996 and posted a 7.5 cents per share final dividend, down from 10.5 cents in 1995/96.
Profits before abnormals fell 45 percent to A$171 million, at the lower end of analysts' expectations of between A$165 million and A$185 million.
Boral said the major cause of the profit fall was the housing downturn in Australia.
"In addition to volumes, intense price competition caused margins to shrink," Boral said.
"Additionally PEP (Performance Enhancement Programmes) will deliver annualised savings of over A$50 million in 1996/97," Berg said.
Boral's shares closed unchanged at A$3.01 on Wednesday.
